NewsLines.HeadLine: Europe grapples with re-elected Schroeder on Iraq

NewsLine.NewsLineText: GERMANY-REACTION:Europe grapples with re-elected Schroeder on Iraq

body.p: By Howard Goller

LONDON, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Europeans came to grips on Monday with Gerhard Schroeder's re-election victory, accusing the German chancellor of trying to score political points while fraying ties with Washington over Iraq.
Caught in a tight campaign, the German leader had voiced virulent opposition to any U.S. military action against Iraq, even with United Nations backing, in his quest for re-election.
"It will have a bad effect on the (European Union's) security policy," Italian European Union Affairs Minister Rocco Buttiglione insisted in an interview published on Monday.

"We will have to split on this point because it is important that there are no divisions between the United States, the United Nations and Europe over Iraq," he told the Corriere della Sera newspaper.

A columnist in Britain's Times newspaper said it took "a certain talent" for Schroeder to make an issue of Iraq even though "the chances of the U.S. army requesting that a regiment of panzers be sent to the Middle East were always nil".
"While George W. Bush deliberately seeks to inspire 'regime change' in Baghdad, Saddam has accidentally prevented one from occurring in Berlin," wrote the columnist, Tim Hames.

But British Prime Minister Tony Blair, who is U.S. President George W. Bush's most outspoken ally in the campaign against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, tried to play down differences with Germany on Monday.

Asked if Blair had been concerned by the anti-American rhetoric from Schroeder's side, a spokesman for the British leader said: "The British government has its position and the German government has its own position."

"In terms of his (Blair's) own dealings with Chancellor Schroeder on important international matters, he has always valued that relationship and will continue to engage with the German government in the months to come," he told reporters.
The spokesman said the two leaders were keen to meet soon.

In a first step toward repairing the damage with Washington, Schroeder said on Monday his justice minister, who was embroiled in a row last week over alleged remarks linking U.S. President George W. Bush to Adolf Hitler, would step down.
EU ENLARGEMENT
Some Europeans hailed the end of the German election campaign as a boost to the eastward enlargement of the 15-nation European Union.

But some voiced doubts whether the German leader, his majority cut sharply in Sunday's election, would have enough power to ensure that Germany, the world's third largest economy, remained what they called "the engine" of Europe.

They feared Schroeder would find it hard to enact painful reforms because his centre-left government of Social Democrats and Greens got a majority of just nine over the combined opposition parties, down from 21 at the last election.
"It is hard to imagine that after such a result Germany can continue to be a role model for its neighbours and a motor for Europe," former Italian diplomat Sergio Romano wrote in Corriere della Sera.

The accession talks have been on hold for months on the crucial issues of agricultural support and regional aid for the 10 leading candidates, awaiting a new German government able to take decisions on financing enlargement.
Both candidates backed enlargement, differing only slightly on the pace of agricultural reform.
Now that the election was over, Dutch Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende said: "Congratulations to Mr Schroeder. It has been a good campaign...Enlargement will continue."
FRANCE, RUSSIA, TURKEY
French President Jacques Chirac, who only a few months ago won re-election himself, tried to put aside chilly relations.
The two formerly close allies have repeatedly clashed over various subjects, including plans for EU enlargement, since Schroeder first came to power in 1998.

"In this decisive period for the European Union, on the eve of a big enlargement and a profound reform of its institutions, our two countries must continue to be engines in the construction of Europe," Chirac said.
Russian President Vladimir Putin congratulated Schroeder. The Kremlin issued a statement saying: "Both sides expressed a commitment to further steady development of Russian-German relations".
But perhaps no country rejoiced more in Schroeder's victory than Turkey did.
Relieved that Schroeder came from behind to defeat conservative Edmund Stoiber, newspapers published headlines reading: "Thank you, Germany" and "Turkey got what it wanted."

Stoiber had opposed distant EU candidate Turkey's eventual membership in the bloc. Half a million Turks won German passports recently after citizenship laws were eased during Schroeder's administration.
(Reuters World Desk +44 207 542 7917)
